results.title: The Searchers [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: John Ford, Merian C. Cooper and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Ethan Edwards (John Wayne) resolves to find his niece, abducted by Indians at the close of the Civil War. It is an odyssey which takes five years, by the end of which he plans to take revenge on the Indians for the friends and family he has lost. John Ford used sumptuous Monument Valley as a background for this his most poetic and complex western. Cast includes Vera Miles and a young Natalie Wood. Based on a novel by Alan Le May. A documentary written and directed by Nick Redman entitled, “A Turning of the earth: John Ford, John Wayne and ‘The Searchers’”, featuring outtakes, home movies and the original theatrical trailer precedes the film. Introduced by Patrick Wayne.

results.title: The Wild bunch [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Sam Peckinpah, Phil Feldman and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: In 1913, a gang known as “The Wild Bunch”, rode into a Texas border town disguised as U.S. soldiers. Silently they entered the railroad office and robbed it. Perched on the rooftops above was a ring of hired gunmen waiting for their prey. When the gang emerged they opened fire. An exciting, provocative and influential film that breathed new life into Westerns, it brings together an all-star cast of fine actors at the peak of their talents to play the band of magnificent losers in a dying, lawless West. A documentary, “The Wild Bunch: an album in montage”, as well as a new introduction by Ernest Borgnine precedes the movie.

results.title: Unforgiven [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Clint Eastwood, Malpaso Company and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Clint Eastwood’s film is an exciting modern classic that rode off with four 1992 Academy Awards including Best Picture and Director. Eastwood and Morgan Freeman play retired down-on-their-luck outlaws who pick up their guns one last time to collect a bounty offered by the vengeful prostitutes of the remote Wyoming town of Big Whiskey. Richard Harris is an ill-fated interloper, a colourful killer for hire called English Bob. Gene Hackman is the sly and brutal local sheriff whose brand of law enforcement ranges from unconventional to ruthless. Big trouble is coming to Big Whiskey.

results.title: Tribute to a bad man
results.creator_credit: Robert Wise, Sam Zimbalist and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: James Cagney stars as a no-nonsense land baron Jeremy Rodock, who plays by his own rules, his own sense of justice and his own code of honour. Young cowhand Steve Miller (Don Dubbins) learns the hard way what it mean’s to incur Rodock’s wrath when he falls in love with the beautiful Jocasta Constantine (Irene Papas), whom Rodock considers his property. Through the example of the even-tempered Miller, however, Rodock rediscovers his own essential humanity. This excellent adaptation of Jack Schaefer’s short story features early screen appearances by Vic Morrow and Lee Van Cleef.

results.title: Memphis Belle
results.creator_credit: Michael Caton-Jones, Catherine Wyler, David Puttnam and Bountiful Company Ltd
results.brief_description: The Memphis Belle is a B-17 World War II bomber, piloted by a young crew of ten men on dangerous bombing raids into Europe. Thus far they have flown 24 perilous missions, they are about to embark on mission 25 - a daylight raid on Bremen that is there most dangerous to date, and the one thing that stands between them and home. The expectations for success were high, as completing the 25th mission would earn the crew the prestigious position of being the first crew to complete all 25 missions in the 8th Airforce. Cinemagoers first saw the exploits of the Memphis Belle in a 1944 documentary by William Wyler (also available in the collection). Using this documentary as inspiration, the producers David Puttnam and Catherine Wyler embarked on a mission to produce a film that included real B-17’s and other vintage planes, as well as impressive models and authentic footage as a backdrop to the story of friendship, action and heroics. The cast includes Matthew Modine, Eric Stoltz, Tate Donovan, D. B. Sweeney, Billy Zane, Sean Astin, Harry Connick Jnr, Reed Edward Diamond, Coutney Gains and Neil Giuntoli.

results.title: White hunter: black heart
results.creator_credit: Clint Eastwood and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: One of Clint Eastwood’s most engaging films, “White hunter, black heart” is based on Peter Vietel’s novel about the location shoot of John Huston’s immortal “The African Queen”. The focus, however, is never on Bogie and Hepburn, but rather on the obsessive director who is determined to turn his new film project into a grand personal quest, hunting a wild elephant. Cast includes Clint Eastwood, Jeff Fahey, George Dzundza, Alun Armstrong and Marisa Berenson.

results.title: Merrill's marauders
results.creator_credit: Samuel Fuller, Milton Sperling, United States Pictures and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: The viewer is plunged directly into war. The documentary element - the reconstruction of the campaign of General Merrill’s American infantry regiment deep behind Japanese lines in Burma - seems to exist on a level independent of the more stylised attempt to abstract the rhythms of combat and survival. Because he experienced combat at first hand as an infantry man in World War II, Fuller has a certain commitment to represent that reality thus bringing the contradictions between re-creation and generic convention closer to the surface than is usual for the combat genre.

results.title: Thousands cheer
results.creator_credit: George Sidney, Joe Pasternak and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: A professional singer who is also a Colonel’s daughter (Kathryn Grayson), decides to follow in her father’s footsteps and join him by entertaining the troops he has been assigned to train. On the platform prior to departure, she meets Private Eddy Marsh (Gene Kelly) who impulsively kisses her in the belief that she is one of the women farewelling the troops. After the train has left the two meet again, and Kathryn jokingly says that she followed the private on board to propose to him. When Eddy goes to her cabin to discuss the issue, he finds Kathryn there with her father, and demands to be transferred to another division, the Army Air Corps. On the advice from friends that the quickest way to get a transfer is to ingratiate himself with the Colonel’s daughter, Eddy soon develops a relationship with her. Eddy’s attentions suit Kathryn too, as she uses the ruse of saying that she’s fallen in love to try and bring her mother to see her, and be united with her ex-husband - Kathryn’s father. Eddy takes Kathryn to see the Flying Corbinos, a trapeze act in which Eddie used to be the star, but had to abandon when forced into National Service. Eddy and Kathryn fall in love, and Kathryn gets her wish of her mother being united with her father, the only problem is she’s come to break up her daughter and the man she now loves. The film culminates in a dazzling array of stars from the MGM payroll including Judy Garland, Mickey Rooney, Red Skelton, Lucille Ball, Eleanor Powell, Ann Sothern, Lena Horn, June Allyson and Donna Reed, as well as Eddy rejoining the Corbino family for a performance for the troops. Cast also includes Mary Astor, John Boles, Ben Blue, Frances Rafferty and Mary Elliott.

results.title: The White cliffs of Dover
results.creator_credit: Clarence Brown, Sidney A. Franklin and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: This filmed interpretation of Alice Duer Miller’s poem features an all star cast of Irene Dunn, Roddy McDowall, Van Johnson, Dame May Whitty and C. Aubrey Smith. A young woman who moves from America to England with her father, meets and falls in love with Sir John Ashwood (Alan Marshal), an English baronet. They marry, and Susan soon falls pregnant, but tragically loses her husband to World War I before her son, John junior is born. Despite the prospect of isolation, she decides to remain in England (young son played by Roddy McDowall, adult son by Peter Lawford). Susan’s painful relationship with war and tragedy is relived years later when her son expresses a wish to go to war like his father. Reluctantly she agrees, as well as becoming a volunteer with the Red Cross. Once again, a mother’s love is placed in the hands of fate as the waiting game begins.
